t: Remember that our fathers were saved at the Red Sea when Pharaoh pursued them with an army,
and now let us cry unto Heaven: if He desireth us, He will remember His covenant with our fathers and will crush this army before us this day.
Then shall all the nations acknowledge that there is One who redeemeth and saveth Israel.
The heathen lifted up their eyes and, seeing the Jews marching against them,
they came forth out of the camp to give battle. The soldiers of Judas sounded the trumpet
and joined battle. The heathen were crushed, they fled into the plain,
but all the enemies that were in the rear fell by the sword. The pursuit reached Gazara and the plains of Idumea, Azotus and Jamnia: about three thousand men fell there.
Having returned from the chase that he had given at the head of his troop,
Judas said to the people: "Be not greedy for spoil, for another battle threateneth us.
Gorgias and his detachment are in the mountain close by us. Stand fast now against our enemies and fight them; after that ye shall gather the spoil in safety.
Judas had scarcely finished speaking when a section was seen spying from the top of the mountain.
It saw that their own had had to flee and that the camp had been a prey to the flames: the smoke that was seen still manifested it.
Such a spectacle filled them with panic. Seeing moreover in the plain the army of Judas ready for battle,
they all fled to the land of the Philistines.
Judas then returned for the plundering of the camp. Much coined gold and silver was carried off, stuffs dyed with purple and blue purple, and other great riches.
The Jews, on their return, praised and blessed Heaven, saying: "He is good, and His love endureth forever!
A signal deliverance hath been wrought this day in Israel.
Those of the heathen who had escaped came to announce to Lysias all that had happened.
This news upset him and made him lose courage, for affairs with Israel had not been as he would have wished, and the result was the contrary of what the king had commanded.
The following year, however, Lysias gathered sixty thousand chosen men and five thousand horsemen in order to overcome the Jews.
They came into Idumea and encamped at Bethsur. Judas marched to meet them with ten thousand men.

When he saw this mighty army, he prayed in these words: "Thou art blessed, savior of Israel, Thou who hast broken the attack of the mighty warrior by the hand of Thy servant David, and who hast delivered the camp of the Philistines into the hands of Jonathan, son of Saul, and his armor-bearer.
In like manner shut up this army in the hands of Israel, Thy people; let them receive only shame from their strength and their cavalry.
Sow panic in their ranks, melt away the assurance they put in their strength, and let them be shaken by their defeat.
Overthrow them under the sword of those who love Thee, and may all who know Thy name praise Thee in the hymns!
They came to blows and there fell of the army of Lysias up to five thousand men, and that in hand-to-hand fighting.

Seeing the rout of his army and the intrepidity of the soldiers of Judas who were ready to live or die courageously, Lysias retraced the road to Antioch where he recruited foreigners to return to Judea with more troops than before.
Then Judas and his brothers said: "Behold, our enemies are crushed, let us go up to purify the sanctuary and make the dedication.
The whole army assembled and they went up to Mount Zion.
There they saw the holy place desolate, the altar profaned, the gates burned, shrubs grown in the courts as in a wood or on a mountain, and the chambers destroyed.
Then they tore their garments, mourned a great mourning and scattered ashes on their heads.
They then fell face to the ground and, at the signal given by the trumpets, they cried out toward Heaven.
Judas gave orders to men to fight those who were in the Citadel until he had cleansed the sanctuary.
Then he chose priests without stain and zealous for the Law,
who purified the sanctuary and relegated the stones of defilement to an unclean place.
They deliberated on what should be done with the altar of burnt offerings, which had been profaned,
and there came to them the happy idea of suppressing it for fear that it should become for them a subject of reproach, due to the fact that the pagans had defiled it. They demolished it
and deposited its stones on the mountain of the House in a suitable place, awaiting the coming of a prophet who would pronounce judgment on them.
They took uncut stones, according to the Law, and built a new altar on the model of the previous one.
They repaired the sanctuary and the interior of the House and sanctified the courts.
Having made new sacred utensils, they brought into the Temple the candlestick, the altar of incense and the table.
They burned incense on the altar and lit the lamps of the candlestick which shone inside the Temple.
They placed the loaves on the table, hung the curtains and completed all that they had undertaken.
On the twenty-fifth of the ninth month - named Kislev - in the year one hundred and forty-eight, they arose at daybreak
and offered a lawful sacrifice on the new altar of burnt offerings which they had built.
The altar was inaugurated to the sound of hymns, zithers, lyres and cymbals, at the same time and the same day as the pagans had profaned it.
The whole people prostrated themselves to worship, then they sent up praise toward Heaven which had led them to success.
For eight days they celebrated the dedication of the altar, offering burnt offerings with rejoicing and the sacrifice of communion and thanksgiving.
They adorned the facade of the Temple with crowns of gold and shields, renewed the entrances as well as the chambers which they provided with doors.
Great joy reigned among the people and the reproach inflicted by the pagans was erased.

Judas decided with his brothers and the whole assembly of Israel that the days of the dedication of the altar should be celebrated in their time each year for eight days, starting on the twenty-fifth of the month of Kislev, with joy and rejoicing.
They built at that time all around Mount Zion high walls and strong towers, for fear that the nations might come as before to trample these places.
Judas placed a garrison there to guard it. He fortified Bethzur so that the people might have a fortress facing Idumea.
When the nations round about heard that the altar had been rebuilt and the sanctuary re-established as it was before, they were greatly angered
and decided to exterminate the descendants of Jacob who lived in their midst; they began to operate murders and expulsions among the people.
Judas waged war on the sons of Esau in Idumea, in the land of Akrabattene, because they were besieging the Israelites. He struck them a great blow, drove them back and seized their spoils.
He also remembered the wickedness of the sons of Baïân who were for the people a snare and a trap by the ambushes they set for him on the roads.
Having blocked them in their towers, he besieged them and devoted them to anathema; he set fire to these towers and burned them with all who were in them.
Then he went to the Ammonites, where he found a strong troop and a numerous people commanded by Timothy.
He fought many battles against them; they were crushed before him and he cut them to pieces.
He took Jazer and the villages of its jurisdiction, and returned to Judea.
The nations in Gilead coalesced against the Israelites who lived in their territory in order to exterminate them, and these took refuge in the fortress of Dathema.
They sent letters to Judas and his brothers written thus: "The nations that surround us are coalesced against us to exterminate us.
They are preparing to come and take the fortress where we have found refuge and it is Timothy who commands their army.
Come now and snatch us from their hands, for already many of us have perished.

All our brothers established in the land of Tobiah have been put to death, their wives and children have been taken into captivity, their goods taken and about a thousand men have perished in these places.
They were still reading these letters, when other messengers arrived from Galilee, their garments torn, bearing the same news:
"From Ptolemais, they said, from Tyre and Sidon, they have coalesced against us with all the Galilee of the Nations to exterminate us.

When Judas and the people had heard these discourses, they held a great assembly to deliberate on what they should do in favor of their brothers in the throes of tribulation and the attacks of the enemies.
Judas said to his brother Simon: "Choose men for thyself and go deliver thy brothers who are in Galilee; I and Jonathan, my brother, will go to Gileaditis.
He left in Judea Joseph, son of Zachariah, and Azariah, chief of the people, with the rest of the army to keep guard.
He gave them this order: "Govern this people and do not engage in battle with the nations until our return.
To Simon were assigned three thousand men to go to Galilee, to Judas eight thousand men for the Gileaditis.
Having therefore gone into Galilee, Simon fought several battles against the pagans, who were swept away before him;
he pursued them to the gate of Ptolemais. They had left about three thousand men on the ground, whose spoils he collected.
He took with him the Jews of Galilee and Arbatta with their wives, their children and all their possessions, and brought them to Judea in the midst of overflowing joy.
Meanwhile Judas Maccabeus and Jonathan, his brother, crossed the Jordan and marched three days in the desert.
They met the Nabataeans who received them with peaceful sentiments and told them all that had happened to their brothers in Gileaditis
and how many of them were locked up in Bosora, in Bosor, in Alema, in Chaspho, in Maked and in Karnain, which are all strong and large cities;

that there were also some locked up in the other cities of Gileaditis and that their enemies had resolved for tomorrow to attack these strongholds, to seize them and to exterminate in a single day all those who were there.

And it came to pass, that Judas turned aside suddenly unto Bosora, by way of the wilderness, and took the city: and he smote all the males with the edge of the sword, and took all their spoil, and set the city on fire.
And he departed thence by night, and went toward the fortress.
And when it was day, behold, an exceeding great host came to meet them, both of Jews and Gentiles, to fight against them.
And when Judas saw that the host was come near, and that the battle was ready to begin, he said unto his men,
Fight this day for your brethren.
So he went forth behind them in three companies, who sounded their trumpets, and cried with prayer.
Then the host of Timotheus, perceiving that it was Maccabeus, fled from him: wherefore he smote them with a great slaughter; so that there were slain of them that day about eight thousand men.
After this, Judas turned aside to Alema, and fought against it, and took it, and slew all the males therein, and took the spoils thereof, and burned it with fire.
And after that he departed thence, and took Chaspho, Maked, Bosor, and the other cities of Gilead.
But after these things gathered Timotheus another host, and encamped against Raphon beyond the brook.
Then Judas sent to espy out the host: who brought him word, saying, All the heathen that be round about us are gathered unto them, even a very great host.
There are hired men of Arabia with them, and they encamp beyond the brook, ready to come and fight against thee. So Judas went toward them.
Then said Timotheus unto the captains of his host, When Judas cometh near the brook, if he pass over first unto us, we shall not be able to withstand him; for he will mightily prevail against us.
But if he be afraid, and encamp beyond the river, we shall go over unto him, and prevail against him.
Now when Judas came near the brook, he set the scribes of the people by the brook, and commanded them, saying, Suffer no man to encamp, but let all come and fight.
So he went first over the brook, and all the people followed him: and he slew all the heathen before them, and they cast away their weapons, and fled unto the temple at Carnaim.
Then took he the city, and burned the temple with all that were therein. Thus was Carnaim subdued, neither could they stand any longer before Judas.
And Judas gathered together all the Israelites that were in Gilead, to bring them unto the land of Judah, a very great multitude, both small and great, with their wives, and children, and baggage.
Now when they came unto Ephron, a great city in the way, and strongly fortified, they could not turn from it, either on the right hand or on the left, but must needs pass through the midst of it.
But they of the city shut them out, and stopped up the gates with stones.
